A president of a South Dakota Indian tribe has gone on record as stating her tribe may be willing to offer abortions if the State's ban is withheld. 
 
 http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/12101999
 
 The Attorney General has stated there is precious little the state can do since the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation is a sovereign land. However, there was this caveat:
 
 
 ...providing and receiving abortions would be illegal if the person performing it and the woman were both non-Indian.

 
 Simple enough to qualify, don't you think?

A president of a South Dakota Indian tribe has gone on record as stating her tribe may be willing to offer abortions if the State's ban is withheld. 
 
 http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/12101999
 
 The Attorney General has stated there is precious little the state can do since the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation is a sovereign land. However, there was this caveat:
 
 
 
 Simple enough to qualify, don't you think?

 
 What would be the legal precedent to stop non-Indians from performing or receiving abortions on sovereign lands?

What would be the legal precedent to stop non-Indians from performing or receiving abortions on sovereign lands?

 
 I suppose the fact that Indian law only applies to its people. Who qualifies as an Indian is another matter. Many people who have as little as one-tenth Indian blood qualify for liberal hunting privileges here in Minnesota.
I guess I'm still confused. If non-Indians were on sovereign lands, wouldn't the laws of that land apply to residents and non-residents? How would S. Dakota laws be applied to the sovereign land?

If non-Indians were on sovereign lands, wouldn't the laws of that land apply to residents and non-residents? 
 
 

 
 Non-Indians committing an offense in a reservation would be subject to Indian law, yes. So you're angling that since abortion isn't illegal now in Indian reservations--that we know of--anyone doing it in their jurisdiction is safe from prosecution?

Non-Indians committing an offense in a reservation would be subject to Indian law, yes. So you're angling that since abortion isn't illegal now in Indian reservations--that we know of--anyone doing it in their jurisdiction is safe from prosecution?

 
 I don't know, I'm not a lawyer, just curious as I watch our civil rights crumble. Indian gambling casinos run 24/7 surrounded by states where casino gambling is illegal, yet residents of that state (and others) travel to and from the casinos without being accused of breaking a state law. 
 
 What would be the difference of someone traveling to and from Mexico, a sovereign nation, for purposes of an abortion and to and from Indian sovereign lands for the same purpose? Abortion is fortunately still a states right, which should deny federal interstate commerce regulation as no federal law is being broken. 
 
 I'm trying to understand the basis of the South Dakota AG's statement of Indian nation abortions being limited to Indians and can't make any sense of it. Roadblocks at Indian lands with all non-Indian females submitting to MRIs going in and, if pregnant going in, MRIs when exiting? Non-Indian MDs being refused licensing if they're employed on Indian lands where an abortion might take place? Maybe current administration will invade that Indian nation offering abortions by classifying abortions as potential WMDs to adjoining South Dakota?

Hey, why the heck couldn't the sovereign nations of Native American reservations hire foreign contractors?
 
 George W. Bush does that all the time on behalf of the sovereign nation of the United States. Isn't Halliburton an offshore entity that doesn't have to pay United States taxes on the profits it receives from the American taxpayer?
